ðŸ”¥ havn | Rust
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: Network port scanning for identifying open ports on a target address or IP.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Fast port scanning â€¢ Configurable options â€¢ Asynchronous Tokio multithreading â€¢ Docker compatibility â€¢ Small binary size (<1mb)
ðŸ“– Summary: havn is a fast and configurable port scanner written in Rust, utilizing asynchronous Tokio multithreading for efficient scanning. It offers reasonable defaults and configurable options, making it suitable for various scanning needs across multiple platforms, including Docker.
ðŸ”— Links: â€¢ View Project ================ ðŸ”“ Open Source

ðŸ”¥ autocomplete | TypeScript
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: Implementing autocomplete functionality in web applications.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Fast autocomplete functionality â€¢ Support for various data sources (static, Algolia, recent searches) â€¢ Full control over DOM elements â€¢ Accessibility attributes â€¢ Virtual DOM compatibility (React, Vue, etc.)
ðŸ“– Summary: The `autocomplete` library is a JavaScript library designed to enable developers to quickly build autocomplete experiences in their applications. It provides the core functionality for handling user input, fetching suggestions from various data sources, and rendering the autocomplete UI, while giving developers full control over the DOM elements used for output.
ðŸ”— Links: â€¢ View Project â€¢ Homepage ================ ðŸ”“ Open Source

ðŸ”¥ maildrop | CSS
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: Receiving emails on a disposable address for privacy and convenience.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Random email generation â€¢ Custom email addresses â€¢ Password-protected inboxes â€¢ Clean UI â€¢ Easy setup
ðŸ“– Summary: Maildrop is a self-hostable, open-source disposable email service. It allows users to receive emails at randomly generated addresses on their own domain, which is useful for signing up for services without revealing a personal email address or creating multiple accounts.
ðŸ”— Links: â€¢ View Project â€¢ Homepage ================ ðŸ”“ Open Source

ðŸŒŸ howdy | Python
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: Password-free authentication on Linux systems using facial recognition.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Facial authentication â€¢ PAM integration â€¢ IR camera support â€¢ Support for multiple Linux distributions (Ubuntu, Debian, Arch Linux, Fedora, openSUSE)
ðŸ“– Summary: Howdy provides Windows Hello-style facial authentication for Linux systems. It leverages IR emitters and cameras for facial recognition, enabling password-free authentication for login, screen lock, sudo, and other PAM-integrated functions.
ðŸ”— Links: â€¢ View Project ================ ðŸ”“ Open Source

âœ¨ DiffMem | Python
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: Long-term memory storage and retrieval for AI agents, particularly in conversational systems, where the ability to track and query the evolution of information is important.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Git-based version control for memory â€¢ Markdown files for human-readable storage â€¢ In-memory BM25 index for fast retrieval â€¢ Differential intelligence using Git diffs and logs
ðŸ“– Summary: DiffMem is a Git-based memory backend for AI agents and conversational systems. It leverages Git for version control and Markdown files for human-readable storage, enabling efficient tracking and retrieval of information. The system uses an in-memory BM25 index for fast, explainable search, making it suitable for long-horizon AI applications where memories evolve over time.
ðŸ”— Links: â€¢ View Project ================ ðŸ”“ Open Source

ðŸ”¥ blender-mcp | Python
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: Enabling Claude AI to control and interact with Blender for 3D modeling and scene creation tasks.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Two-way communication between Claude AI and Blender â€¢ Object manipulation (create, modify, delete) â€¢ Material control (apply and modify materials and colors) â€¢ Scene inspection (get detailed information) â€¢ Code execution (run arbitrary Python code from Claude)
ðŸ“– Summary: BlenderMCP connects Blender to Claude AI, enabling prompt-assisted 3D modeling, scene creation, and manipulation through the Model Context Protocol (MCP). It allows Claude to directly interact with and control Blender, facilitating tasks like object manipulation, material control, and scene inspection via a socket-based server.
ðŸ”— Links: â€¢ View Project ================ ðŸ”“ Open Source
